I read through Bob's post below and I find it a really interesting and good=

aproach.
We often talk about convincing management and it can be frustrati=
ng indeed
but why do we have to convince /management/?
I find it to be more=
 important and /at the very least/ equally hard to
convince fellow /develop=
ers/ about the benefits of unittests.

To me unittesting is a development m=
ethodology that makes me go faster/feel
more comfortable with my deliveries=
 etc etc.
So, If I'm right about that and beleive in that: why should I ask=
 for
permission? If i just start unit-testing and as a result of that deliv=
er
better code faster, hopefully the better quality will be evident and spe=
ak
for itself.

We make so many descisions we don't ask permission for like=
 "is it ok to
remove this dead code?, can I use a factory here?,
can I draw=
 a UML-diagram on the whiteboard?, can I save it in
documentation?, can I c=
all a designmeeting?" so why is unit-testing
different?

I think, if you ma=
nage to convince your team /first/ then management is as
good as convinced =
when the results start showing.
I think by example is the best way to go, s=
tart with your self and influence
those around you.

/if/ you are convinced=
 about the benefits of unittesting then /not/ doing
unittesting would be un=
professional since you choose not to do it.
So start doing it and infect th=
e others. Don't have managment inject the
virus into an unwilling team by p=
lacing demands on testcoverage etc.
That will rebound in my experience.

So=
, what do you think? Should we tell the story to our fellow developers
inst=
ead of management?
/J

> In the 19=

n architect who designed a 138 story glass tower for a

 William Holden. On the afternoon of the opening

utility room. A security guard, played

arning from a heat sensor, but the

cognize it as a fire and did not

r saw the smoke on a video

e fire department

>
> When the fire department arrived, the fir=
e chief, played by Steve

t automatically reverse

tem was working. The

he floor with the

> The story revealed th=
at the builder needed to cut $4 million from

emanded that $2 million come from the cost

n order to accomplish this, the electrical
> subcontractor, played by Richa=
rd Chamberlain, changed the

bustness of the

irements of the

ions in other

epartment was unable to successfully fight the fire and the

imately had to blow up the water tanks on an upper floor to

any people lost their lives and the building was

> Now how doe=
s this relate to software?
> The glass tower is our application. Paul Newma=
n is the Software

onality desired

>=
 But the high level tests passed

in the

ons and use values untested prior to release. Problems with

d logic due to untested corner cases are revealed. New

ks previously working functionality but no one knows
> this because the pre=
vious functionality had no low level test to reveal

 these problems can be tested for with low level

t the straw harvest was poor so the

is cut in half. No one tests

hen the fourth level is

s destroy a car in a crash test without first

 of the bumper and other related components

>
=

ceramic tiles that line its surface or are the tiles tested on Earth

t?
